questions.question:
the following resolution rule is used in logic programming:
Derive clause(P \(\vee\) Q) from clauses (P \(\vee\) R),(Q \(\vee \neg\) JR)
Which of the following statements related to this rule is FASLE?

(GATE CSE 2003)
options:
A.

\(((P \vee R) \wedge (Q \vee \neg R)) \Rightarrow (P \vee Q)\) is logically valid

B.

\((P \vee Q) \Rightarrow ((P \vee R)\wedge (Q \vee \neg R))\) is logically valid

C.

\((P \vee Q)\) is satisfiable if and only if \((P \vee R)\wedge (Q \vee \neg R)\) is satisfiable

D.

\((P \vee Q)\Rightarrow\) FALSE if and only if both P and Q are unsatisfiable
questions.correct_answer:
B.

\((P \vee Q) \Rightarrow ((P \vee R)\wedge (Q \vee \neg R))\) is logically valid
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Let G = (V,E) be a direction graph with n vertices. A path from \(v_{i}\) to \(v_{i}\) in G is sequence of vertices (\(v_{i}\),\(v_{i+1}\),....., \(v_{j}\)) such that (\(v_{k}\),\(v_{k+1}\))\(\in\)E for all k in i through j - 1. A simple path is a path in which no vertex appears more than once.
Let A be an n x n array initialized as follows.
\(A[j,k]=\left\{\begin{matrix} 1 & if (j,k) \in E \\ 0& otherwise \end{matrix}\right.\)
Consider the following algorithm

 for i = 1 to n
   for j = 1 to n
      for k = 1 to n
         A [j , k] = max (A[j, k] (A[j, i] + A [i, k]);
Which of the following statements is necessarily true for all j and k after terminal of the above algorithm?

(GATE CSE 2003)
options:
B.

If \(A[j,k]\geq n- 1\), then G has a Haniltonian cycle

C.

If there exists a path from j to k,A[j,k] contains the longest path lens from j to k

D.

If there exists a path from j to k , every simple path from j to k contain most A[j,k] edges
questions.correct_answer:
D.

If there exists a path from j to k , every simple path from j to k contain most A[j,k] edges
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
In a permutation \(a_1.....a_n\) of n distinct integers, an inversion is a pair \((a_i, a_j) \) such that \(i \lt j\) and \(a_i \gt a_j\).

If all permutation are equally likely, what is the expected number of inversions in a randomly chosen permutation of 1.....n?

(GATE CSE 2003)

questions.question:
Let \(\Sigma\) = (a, b, c, d, e) be an alphabet. We define an encoding scheme as follows : g(a) = 3, g(b) = 5, g(c) = 7, g(d) = 9, g(e) = 11.
Let \(p_{i}\) denote the i-th prime number (\(p_{i}\)=2).
For a non-empty string \(s=a_{1}...a_{n}\), where each \(a_{i} \in \Sigma\), define \(f(i)=\prod_{i=1}^{n}{P_{i}}^{g(a_{i})}\).
For a non-empty sequence \(< s_{j},...,s_{n} >\) of strings from \(\Sigma^{+}\),
define \(h()=\prod_{i=1}^{n}{P_{i}}^{f(s_{i})}\)
Which of the following numbers is the encoding, h, of a non-empty sequence of strings?

(GATE CSE 2003)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

h(D) = {x | x \(\in\) A, f (x) \(\in\) D}, for all subsets D of B.
